147.01  COMPREHENSIVE PLAN.
   (a)   The Planning Commission of the City, hereby adopts a comprehensive
plan to provide for the establishment in the City of zoning districts within
which the use of land, and/or structures for residence, trade or industry, the
density of population, the height, the number of stories, the area, the size
and the location of buildings, yards, courts and open spaces, the light and
ventilation of buildings, and development within floodways may be regulated;
providing for the discontinuance of nonconforming uses and structures;
providing definitions for certain terms; providing for amendments, supplements
or changes thereto; establishing a Board of Zoning Appeals, providing for
conflicts with other resolutions; and providing penalties for violation of this
resolution; in accordance with the provisions of Ohio R.C. 713.06 to 713.13,
all of which is marked Exhibit “A” and “B” attached to original Resolution 1060
and made a part hereof.
   (b)   The Planning Commission hereby certifies the foregoing comprehensive
plan to Council to be placed on file with the Clerk of Council for public
examination pursuant to the Ohio Revised Code.  (Res. 1060.  Passed 11-28-70.)
147.02  MASTER PLAN APPROVAL.
   The Master Plan certified to Council by the Planning Commission is hereby
ratified and approved. 
(Ord. 1178.  Passed 12-17-73.)
147.03  RULES AND PROCEDURES.
   The Planning Commission may by motion adopt such rules and procedures as it
deems necessary to the conduct of its affairs.
(Ord. 98-16.  Passed 3-16-98.)
CHAPTER 148
Swimming Pool Board
148.01   Creation; members; terms.
148.02   Powers and duties.
148.03   Responsibilities.
148.04   Solicitation of input.
148.05   Rules and regulations.
148.06   Removal from office.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Council power to create -  see CHTR. Sec.
7.01
 
 
148.01  CREATION; MEMBERS; TERMS.
   There is hereby created a Swimming Pool Board consisting of five members who
shall be electors of the Municipality of Germantown or electors of German
Township and hold no compensated position in such governmental entities who
shall be appointed by the Mayor subject to confirmation by Council.  All
members of the Swimming Pool Board shall serve for a term of three years,
provided, however, that initially there will be no appointment for a term
ending December 31, 1990; two appointments for terms ending December 21, 1991;
and two appointments for terms ending December 31, 1992 in order to provide for
overlapping of terms.  Thereafter, the terms will be for three years.  (Ord.
90-35.  Passed 7-2-90.)
148.02  POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Swimming Pool Board shall act in an advisory capacity and make
recommendations and reports to Council regarding the items set forth in Section
148.03 herein concerning the Germantown Swimming Pool.  (Ord. 99-34.  Passed 6-
7-99.)
148.03  RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Board, in its advisory capacity, shall review and provide
recommendations on the following:
   (a)   Salaries of Pool Manager, Assistant Manager, guards and concession
personnel;
   (b)   Daily admission fees, costs of season passes and opening and closing
dates of the pool;
   (c)   Any special admissions policy such as the cost of pool rental for
parties, special group rates, etc.;
   (d)   The Pool Manual, which establishes municipal policy and personnel
responsibilities for day-to-day operation of the pool.  The Pool Manager shall
be reviewed annually;
   (e)   Water treatment policy, chemical use and pool/equipment operational
procedures;
   (f)   New ideas to improve or expand pool services to the community;
   (g)   Maintenance policy and practice at the pool;
   (h)   Long-and short-term maintenance requirements.  Short-term items
include the annual pool opening and closing procedures as well as day-to-day
servicing and repair practices and procedures for the pool house, restrooms,
concession area, pump house, pool and yard.  Long-term items include the pool
area and building upkeep such as painting, roofing, fence maintenance, filter/
media replacement, deck repairs, pump overhauls, electrical motor overhaul,
etc.:
   (i)   A list of capital improvement projects for the pool.  This list shall
be prioritized and presented to Council annually.  The Board shall research
innovative ways to fund and implement these projects.  The Board shall work
with the Parks and Recreation Board to obtain an annual funding appropriation
for capital improvement projects;
   (j)   The pool’s budget and expenditures both monthly and annually; and
   (k)   Such other issues that may be requested by Council.
      (Ord. 99-34.  Passed 6-7-99.)
148.04  SOLICITATION OF INPUT.
   The Board shall solicit community input, at least annually, on pool
operations and desired capital improvements.  This citizen input shall be
documented and provided to Council.
   The Board shall survey other community pools and be cognizant of admission
fees, cost of season passes, general operational and maintenance procedures,
capital improvements implemented or planned, and have general knowledge of the
financial health and well-being of other  local pools.  This knowledge and
experience shall be shared with Council so that they may take advantage of
lessons learned in other communities when making decisions regarding the
Germantown Pool.  (Ord. 99-34.  Passed 6-7-99.)
148.05  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Board shall hold a meeting at least once a month and adopt rules and
regulations to conduct its business.  The Board shall keep a complete and
accurate record of its proceedings.
(Ord. 99-34.  Passed 6-7-99.)
148.06  REMOVAL FROM OFFICE.
   The Council of the Municipality of Germantown has the right to remove any
member of the Swimming Pool Board from office for failure to attend three (3)
consecutive regular meetings without being excused by a majority vote of the
Swimming Pool Board.
(Ord.  02-12.  Passed 4-1-02.)
CHAPTER 149
Park and Recreation Board
149.01 Powers and duties.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Creation - see CHTR.
 §7.12
Powers and duties - see CHTR
. §7.13
Land appropriation for parks - see Ohio R.C. 715.21, 719.01
Parks and playgrounds - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 755
 
 
149.01  POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Park and Recreation Board shall have the following duties and
responsibilities:
   (a)    Act in an advisory capacity and make recommendations and reports to
Council in a manner determined by motion of Council, regarding the acquisition,
development, maintenance and operation of park, playgrounds, recreational
facilities and programs of the Municipality where such recommendations may
result in on-going expenditures of moneys generated from the tax levy for park
and recreation services or the Municipality and such other recommendations and
reports as may be requested by the City Manager or Council.
      (Ord. 90-09. Passed 3-5-90.)
   (b)    Coordinate with organized groups concerned with recreational
programs.
   (c)    Stimulate citizen interest in the care and preservation of parks,
historical and scenic sites.
   (d)    Act as trustee for any property, asset or funds donated to the
Municipality for park or recreational purposes; provided the donor designates
or provides for the Board to act as such trustee; in such event, the Board
shall have all powers necessary to carry out the purposes of the trust.
   (e)    To provide for the scheduling of all events to be held at any park
and/or recreational facility.
   (f)    To develop, implement and monitor recreational programs and
activities of all citizens.
   (g)    To hold a meeting at least once a month and adopt rules and
regulations to conduct its business and keep a complete and accurate record of
its proceedings; provided further, that a certified copy of such record shall
be competent evidence of its transactions in the courts of the State.
   (h)    Adopt rules and regulations for the operation, protection,
maintenance and care of the real and personal property under its charge;
provided further, than when such rules and regulations are approved by Council,
they shall have the same affect and may be enforced as other ordinances of the
Municipality.
      (Ord. 82-42. Passed 12-20-82. )
   (i)    Notwithstanding any other provisions to the contrary, the Park and
Recreation Board shall have no powers and duties concerning the swimming pool.
      (Ord. 90-33. Passed 7-2-90.)
CHAPTER 150
City Beautiful Commission
150.01   Establishment and objectives.
150.02   Members appointment.
150.03   Terms.
150.04   Rules, records and annual report.
150.05   Removal from office.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to create - see CHTR.
 §7.01
Meetings - see CHTR.
 §7.03
Organization and quorum - see CHTR
. §7.04 et seq.
 
 
150.01  ESTABLISHMENT AND OBJECTIVES.
   (a)   There is hereby established a City Beautiful Commission.
   (b)   The objectives of the Commission shall be as follows:
      (1)   To make specific recommendations to Council for improvements in the
appearance of streets, parks, buildings and other property owned or controlled
by the City.
      (2)   To sponsor, promote, coordinate and otherwise encourage both
individual and collective beautification efforts by business, industry and the
general citizenry.
      (3)   To generate City-wide interest, pride and action related to
beautification through contests, awards and similar programs.
         (Ord. 83-7.  Passed 2-22-83.)
150.02  MEMBERS APPOINTMENT.
   The City Beautiful Commission shall consist of five members who shall be
appointed by Council in the manner as to provide broad geographical
representation.  Members of the Commission shall serve without compensation. 
The Mayor shall appoint one Council member annually, with the approval of
Council, to serve with the Commission; however, such Councilperson shall have
no voting power and shall not hold an office on the Commission.  The Council of
the Municipality may appoint ex-officio, non-voting members to the Commission
as it deems appropriate and necessary.  These ex-officio members can be
residents of the incorporated or unincorporated areas of the Municipality.
(Ord. 04-52.  Passed 8-16-04.)
150.03  TERMS.
   All members of the City Beautiful Commission shall serve for a term of three
years, provided, however, that initially, there will be three one-year terms,
two two-year terms and two three-year terms in order to provide for overlapping
of terms.  Thereafter the terms will be for three years.  The terms of those
members first appointed shall be effective January 1, 1983, and the appointment
of new members to the Commission shall be made effective on January 1 of each
year thereafter.  (Ord. 83-7.  Passed 2-22-83.)
150.04  RULES, RECORDS AND ANNUAL REPORT.
   The City Beautiful Commission shall adopt its own rules and elect its own
officers annually.  It shall keep current and complete records of its meetings
and activities, and shall present an annual report to the Council on its yearly
activities prior to January 31 of each year.
(Ord.  83-7.  Passed 2-22-83.)
150.05  REMOVAL FROM OFFICE.
   The Council of the Municipality of Germantown has the right to remove any
member of the City Beautiful Commission from office for failure to attend three
(3) consecutive regular meetings without being excused by a majority vote of
the City Beautiful Commission.
(Ord.  02-12.  Passed 4-1-02.)

161.02  PAY PERIODS.
   Except as provided in Section
161.07(b), payrolls shall be computed every fourteen days commencing with 12:01
a.m. on Monday and concluding at 12:00 midnight on the following second
Sunday.  Paychecks for the aforementioned computation shall be issued the
Friday following the close of the pay period and shall be available between 8:
00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. at the Municipal Building.
(Ord. 97-51.  Passed 7-21-97.)
161.03  HOURS OF WORK.
   Due to the differences in the operations of the various departments, the
hours of work shall be established by the department head and posted at least
one week in advance of the scheduled work period as provided for each
Department.
(Ord. 86-20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
161.04  ADMINISTRATION DEPARTMENT.
   (a)   Work Periods.  The work period for all employees considered a part of
the Administration Department shall be fourteen days commencing at 12:01 a.m.
Monday and concluding at 12:00 midnight on the following second Sunday.
   (b)   Compensable Time.  All employees included in the Administration
Department shall be compensated at their regular rate of pay for each hour
worked, up to eighty hours, during a work period.  Any hours worked in excess
of eighty hours per work period shall constitute overtime for those employees
eligible under Section
161.04(d).
(Ord. 97-51.  Passed 7-21-97.)
   (c)   Rate of Pay. EDITOR’S NOTE: Former
161.04(c) was repealed by Ordinance 18-42.  See Section
161.015 for current pay rates.
   (d)   Overtime Pay.  The Municipal Manager, Finance Director, and Clerk of
Council/Zoning Compliance Officer shall be ineligible for overtime pay.  All
other employees under this section shall be eligible for overtime pay at the
rate of one and one-half times their regular rate of pay for work in excess of
eighty hours per work period.  Sick leave, vacation leave and personal leave
shall not be considered work and shall not be used in computing overtime when
the overtime is scheduled prior to the work period during which any sick,
vacation or personal leave is taken.  Sick leave, vacation leave and personal
leave shall be considered work and shall be used in computing unscheduled
overtime.
(Ord. 10-48.  Passed 12-20-10.)
161.05  POLICE DEPARTMENT.
   (a)   Work Periods.
      (1)   Police officers.  Pursuant to Section 207(k) of the Fair Labor
Standards Act, hereinafter “Act”, and 29 C.F.R., Part 553, the work period for
all police officers shall be fourteen days commencing at 12:01 a.m. Monday and
concluding at 12:00 midnight on the following second Sunday.
         (Ord. 86-20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
      (2)   Other police personnel.  The work period for all other employees in
the Police Department shall be fourteen days commencing at 12:01 a.m. Monday
and concluding at 12:00 midnight on the following second Sunday. 
         (Ord. 97-51.  Passed 7-21-97.)
   (b)   Pay Periods.
      (1)   Police officers.  Payrolls for all police officers shall be
computed following each fourteen-day work period.  Paychecks for the
aforementioned computation shall be issued no later than the Friday following
the end of each pay period and shall be available between 8:00 a.m. and 4:00
p.m. at the Municipal Building.
      (2)   Other police personnel.  Payrolls for all other employees in the
Police Department shall be computed in accordance with Section
161.02.
         (Ord. 86-20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
   (c)   Compensable Time.
      (1)   Police officers.  All police officers shall be compensated at their
regular rate of pay for each hour worked, up to eighty hours, during a work
period.  Any hours worked in excess of eighty hours shall constitute overtime
for those employees eligible under subsection (e) hereof.
         A.   Off-duty police officers who are required to attend court shall
be credited a minimum of two hours worked.  If attendance exceeds two hours,
the officer shall be credited for the actual number of hours worked.
      (2)   Other police personnel.  All other employees of the Police
Department shall be compensated at their regular rate of pay for each hour
worked, up to eighty hours, during a work period.  Any hours worked in excess
of eighty hours per work period, shall constitute overtime for those employees
eligible under subsection (e) hereof.
         (Ord. 97-51.  Passed 7-21-97.)
   (d)   Rate of Pay.  Council shall, by motion, determine the rate of pay for
each employee at such times as it deems appropriate and necessary and the
Manager is hereby authorized to appoint, suspend or remove any such employee as
provided by the Charter.  The rate of pay for each employee shall be
established in accordance with the following compensation schedule.
(Ord. 10-49.  Passed 12-20-10.)
      (1)(2)   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former subsection (d)(1) and (2) were repealed
by Ordinance 18-42.  See Section
161.015 for current pay rates.)
   (e)   Overtime Pay.  The Chief of Police, Lieutenant and Auxiliary Patrolmen
shall be ineligible for overtime pay.  All other employees under this section
shall be eligible for overtime pay as follows:
      (1)   Police officers.  Overtime pay for police officers shall be at a
rate of one and one-half times their regular rate of pay for work in excess of
eighty hours per work period.
      (2)   Other police personnel.  Overtime pay for all other employees of
the Police Department shall be at a rate of one and one-half times their
regular rate of pay for work in excess of eighty hours per work period.
   Sick leave, vacation leave and personal leave shall not be considered work
and shall not be used in computing overtime. 
(Ord. 97-51.  Passed 7-21-97.)
   (f)   Police Officers serving as Field Training Officers (FTO) shall be
compensated $250.00 per year for this extra duty.
   (g)   Full-time Police Officers shall be entitled to receive $165.00 per
year reimbursement for purchase of supplementary insurance to cover police
officers for legal defense in criminal, civil and administrative matters,
similar to the coverage provided by the Professional Law Enforcement
Association, Legal Defense Fund.
(Ord. 16-16.  Passed 7-5-16.)
161.06  PUBLIC SERVICE DEPARTMENT.
   (a)   Work Periods.  The work period for all employees considered a part of
the Public Service Department shall be fourteen days commencing at 12:01 a.m.
Monday and concluding at 12:00 midnight on the following second Sunday.
   (b)   Compensable Time.  All employees included in the Public Service
Department shall be compensated at their regular rate of pay for each hour
worked, up to eighty hours, during a work period.  Any hours worked in excess
of eighty hours per work period shall constitute overtime for those employees
eligible under subsection (d) hereof.
(Ord. 97-51.  Passed 7-21-97.)
   (c)   Rate of Pay.  Council shall, by motion, determine the rate of pay for
each employee, at such times as it deems appropriate and necessary and the
Manager is hereby authorized to appoint, suspend or remove any such employee as
provided by the Charter.  The rate of pay for each employee shall be
established in accordance with the following compensation schedule.
(Ord. 10-50.  Passed 12-20-10.)
(1)   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former subsection (c)(1) was repealed by Ordinance 18-
42.  See Section
161.015 for current pay rates.)
      (2)   Public Service Department employees who are in an official on-call
status, shall be paid $100.00 per week during the on-call period.
      (3)   The City Manager may develop a bonus structure for Public Service
Department employees who obtain water, wastewater and Service Department
related certifications.  Bonus amounts shall range from $.25 - $1.00 per hour.
         (Ord. 16-30.  Passed 9-6-16.)
   (d)   Overtime Pay.  The Director of Public Service shall be ineligible for
overtime pay.  All other employees under this section shall be eligible for
overtime pay at rate of one and one-half times their regular rate of pay for
work in excess of eighty hours per work period.  Sick leave, vacation leave and
personal leave shall not be considered work and shall not be used in computing
overtime when the overtime is scheduled prior to the work period during which
any sick, vacation or personal leave is taken.  Sick leave, vacation leave and
personal leave shall be considered work and shall be used in computing
unscheduled overtime.
(Ord. 97-51.  Passed 7-21-97.)
161.07  FIRE DEPARTMENT.
   (a)   Work Periods.  Pursuant to Section 207(k) of the Act and 29 C.F.R.,
part 553, the work period for all employees in the Fire Department shall be
twenty-eight days commencing at 12:01 a.m. Monday and concluding at 12:00
midnight on the following fourth Sunday.  (Ord. 86- 20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
   (b)   Pay Periods.  Payrolls for all employees of the Fire Department shall
be computed following each twenty-eight day work period.  Paychecks for the
aforementioned computation shall be issued the Friday following the conclusion
of the work period and shall be available between 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. at
the Municipal Building.
(Ord. 93-42.  Passed 7-6-93.)
   (c)   Rate of Pay.  The rate of pay for each employee shall be established
in accordance with the following compensation schedule:
      (1)   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former subsections (c)(1) and (2) were repealed by
Ordinance 18-42.  See Section
161.015 for current pay rates.
      (3)   The employees of the Fire/EMS Department who work on New Year’s
Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas
Day shall be compensated as follows:
         The employees of the Fire/EMS Department who work on New Year’s Day,
Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day
shall be compensated as follows:
In House Day Crew 12- Hour Sift - (regardless of what day of the week the
holiday falls on)
EMT-B - $60.00 in addition to their normal rate of pay
EMT-I - $66.00 in addition to their normal rate of pay
EMT-P - $72.00 in addition to their normal rate of pay
 
The In House Day Crew shift may be split into two (2) 6-hour shifts 6:00 a.m. -
Noon and Noon-6:00 p.m. with each crew member fulfilling a six (6) hour shift
receiving half of their respective stipend allotment.
Personnel who do not complete the minimum six (6) hour shift in house will not
be eligible for that holiday’s in house stipend.
Paid-On-Call Weekday Nights - Personnel whose regularly assigned weekday night
shift falls on one of the six holidays will receive $3.00 per hour for the
hours of 0000-0600 and 1800-2400 the day of the holiday that the crew member is
available on call for emergency response.  Personnel that respond to a call for
service shall also receive their normal rate of pay.
Firefighters - Personnel that respond to a call for service for fire calls on
one of the six holidays will receive $3.00 an hour in addition to their normal
rate of pay for the hours worked.
         (Ord. 12-61.  Passed 12-4-12.)

compensated as follows:
 
Mayor                $3,000/year until 12/31/06
                    $6,000/year effective 01/01/07

(Ord. 06-42.  Passed 7-17-06.)
   (b)   Appointed Official.  (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former subsection (b) was
repealed by Ordinance 18-42.  See Section
161.015 for current pay rates).
   (c)   Part-Time Employees.
      (1)   Work periods.  The work period for part-time employees shall be
that of the particular department to which the employee is assigned.
      (2)   Pay periods.  The pay periods for part-time employees shall be that
of the particular department to which the employee is assigned.
         (Ord. 86-20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
      (3)   Compensable time.  Except as provided in Section
161.07(c), all part-time employees shall be compensated at their regular rate
of pay for each hour worked, up to eighty hours, during a work period.  Any
hours worked in excess of eighty hours per work period shall constitute
overtime.  Part-time employees shall have all income taxes withheld from their
wages and shall either waive or enroll in the appropriate retirement system as
dictated by State law.
         (Ord. 97-51.  Passed 7-21-97.)
      (4)   Rate of pay.  Council shall, by motion, determine the rate of pay
for each employee, at such times as it deems appropriate and necessary and the
Manager is hereby authorized to appoint, suspend or remove any such employee as
provided by the Charter.  Except as provided in Section
161.07 (d), all part-time employees shall be compensated hourly within the
hourly range below:
         Part-time (unclassified) Minimum wage - $8.00.
         (Ord. 96-74.  Passed 10-7-96.)
      (5)   Overtime pay.  Except as provided in Sections
161.05(e) and
161.07(e), all part-time employees shall be eligible for overtime pay at a rate
of one and one-half times their regular rate of pay for work in excess of
eighty hours per week.  (Ord. 97-51.  Passed 7-21-97.)
   (d)   Seasonal Employees.
      (1)   Employment/work period.  Seasonal employees shall be employed by a
seasonal recreational establishment operated seven months, or less, per year.
      (2)   Compensable time.  All seasonal employees shall be compensated at
their regular rate of pay for each hour worked and shall have income taxes
withheld from their wages and shall either waive or enroll in the appropriate
retirement system as dictated by State law.
         (Ord. 86-20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
      (3)   Rate of pay.  (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former subsection (d)(3) was repealed
by Ordinance 18-42.  See Section
161.015 for current pay rates).
      (4)   Overtime pay.  Seasonal employees shall be ineligible for overtime
pay.
         (Ord. 86-20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
161.09  TEMPORARY EMPLOYEES AND UNSKILLED LABORERS.
   (a)   The Manager shall have authority to appoint, suspend or remove any
unclassified employees of any department, office, board, commission, agency or
authority of the City established by the Charter or by Council, employed on a
temporary or emergency basis in any of the following capacities:
      (1)   Employees of exceptional professional or scientific qualification
engaged as consultants;
      (2)   Secretary of each board and commission established by the Charter
or Council;
      (3)   Temporary employees who are not employed for more than ninety
continuous days or for more than ninety work days in one year;
      (4)   Unskilled laborers as defined and authorized by Council.
   (b)   The Manager shall have such other powers with respect to the
unclassified employees listed in subsection (a) hereof as he has with respect
to classified Municipal employees under the Charter.  (Ord. 86-20.  Passed 7-
21-86.)
161.10  SUPPLEMENTAL MANPOWER CONTRACTORS.
   The Manager may be authorized by motion and majority vote of Council at a
regular or special meeting to execute a supplemental manpower contract with
individuals or firms to perform services of a temporary or emergency nature. 
Each contract shall specifically state that the individual or firm and/or any
employees of such individual or firm performing the service is an independent
contractor and is not an employee of the Municipal government.  As such, the
contractor shall not be eligible for any of the benefits contained within this
chapter.
(Ord. 86-20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
161.11  EMPLOYMENT AND PAY RAISES.
   (a)   Employment. Applicants for employment may be required to submit to a
physical exam at Municipal expense prior to becoming eligible for appointment
to a full-time position.  Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 124.41 and 124.42, an applicant
for an original appointment as a police officer shall be not less than twenty-
one or thirty-five years of age or older, and an applicant for an original
appointment as a firefighter shall be not less than eighteen nor thirty-six
years of age or older.  No person shall receive an original appointment as a
police officer or firefighter unless such applicant presents a certificate by a
licensed physician that such applicant is free of cardiovascular and pulmonary
diseases, and meets the physical requirements necessary to perform the duties
of such position.  Other tests may be required before declaring applicants to
be eligible for appointment, including, but not limited to, polygraph,
psychological and other personnel testing procedures as may be established.
   The thirty-five years of age restriction and physical fitness certificate
described herein shall not apply to candidates for Auxiliary Police Officer
positions, nor candidates for part-time Patrolman positions, who have
previously served as Auxiliary Police Officers for the Municipality of
Germantown without a break in service between the candidate’s service as an
Auxiliary Police Officer and his/her application for the position of part-time
Patrolman.  Such restrictions are hereby waived retroactively for those
currently serving as either Auxiliary Police Officers or part- time Patrolmen
in the Police Department.
(Ord. 08-40.  Passed 1-22-08.)
   (b)   Probationary Period.  An employee entering full-time Municipal service
shall be considered a probationary employee for six months.  If a probationary
employee’s performance is judged by his/her supervisor to be substandard, the
employee may be disciplined or terminated without appeal as determined by the
Manager.  If the probationary employee’s performance is judged satisfactory,
he/she shall be appointed as a permanent employee at the conclusion of his/her
probationary period.  Part-time and seasonal employees shall remain on
probationary status during their employment.
   (c)   Evaluations.  Evaluations of full-time employee performance shall be
conducted each year by the employee’s immediate supervisor on a form and/or
method prescribed by the Manager.  The Manager shall submit a report to Council
setting forth his recommendation with regard to any increases in pay.  Council
shall act upon such recommendations and may or may not grant increases at any
regular or special meeting.  (Ord. 86-20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
161.12  HOLIDAYS AND OTHER OFF DAYS.
   (a)   (1)   All full-time employees shall be granted eight hours regular pay
for the following holidays: New Year’s Eve, New Year’s Day, Martin Luther King
Day, President’s Day, Memorial Day, July 4, Labor Day, Veterans Day,
Thanksgiving Day and the day following Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Eve and
Christmas Day.  An unexcused absence on the day prior to or following a holiday
will be cause for forfeiture of the holiday pay for that holiday.  If a holiday
occurs during a period that the employee is on vacation, sick or personal
leave, no vacation time, sick time or personal leave time will be charged for
that day.
      (2)   In the event a holiday falls on a Sunday, the succeeding Monday
will be observed as the holiday and in the event a holiday falls on a Saturday,
the preceding Friday will be observed as the holiday.
         (Ord. 10-22.  Passed 5-17-10.)
   (b)   All full-time hourly employees who work on the following holidays
shall be compensated at twice their regular pay for each hour worked in
addition to the holiday pay:  Memorial Day, July 4, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day
and Christmas Day.
(Ord. 86-20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
   (c)    All full-time employees shall be granted three personal leave days
per year.
(Ord. 16-16.  Passed 7-5-16.)
 
   (d)   Part-time, seasonal and temporary employees shall not be eligible for
holiday pay or personal leave. 
(Ord. 86-20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
161.13  VACATION LEAVE.
   (a)   For purposes of computing vacation, the date of full-time employment
with the Municipality shall be used to determine eligibility for paid leave;
provided, however, that a person employed by the State or any political
subdivision of the State earning vacation credited currently, is entitled to
have his prior service with any of these employers counted as service with the
Municipality for the purpose of computing the amount of his vacation leave. 
The anniversary date of his employment for the purpose of computing the amount
of vacation leave is the anniversary date of such prior service as provided in
Ohio R.C. 9.44.
   (b)    Unless specified otherwise, all full-time employees shall be eligible
for eighty hours vacation leave at their regular rate of pay after 365 days
(one year) of service.  After six years of service, an employee shall be
entitled to 120 hours vacation leave.  After fifteen years of service,
employees are entitled to 160 hours vacation leave.  After twenty years of
service, employees are entitled to 200 hours of vacation leave.
   (c)   The Manager and department heads in the full-time Municipal service
shall be entitled to eighty hours vacation leave at their regular salary upon
completion of 365 days (one year) of service.  After three years of service,
they shall be eligible for 120 hours vacation leave.  After completion of five
years of service, they shall be entitled to 160 hours vacation leave.
   (d)   No employee shall be allowed to defer unused vacation leave into the
next year.  An employee may work in lieu of leave at the discretion of the
department head and the Manager and may be compensated at his regular rate in
addition to his leave payment.
   (e)   Vacation leave accrues only at the end of each full year of service
and shall not be pro-rated for a partial year of service.  An employee
terminating service shall be granted accrued but unused vacation leave unless
termination is by dismissal or without two weeks notice in which case, accrued
vacation pay shall be forfeited.
   (f)   The Manager is authorized to establish times and schedules during
which vacations may be taken in order to avoid disruption of Municipal service.
   (g)   Part-time, temporary and seasonal employees shall be ineligible for
vacation leave. 
(Ord.  86-20.  Passed 7-21-86; Ord. 16-16.  Passed 7-5-16.)
161.14  SICK LEAVE.
   (a)   All full-time employees shall accrue sick leave at a rate of ten hours
per month (equivalent to 2.308 hours of sick leave credit per week).  An
employee shall accrue sick leave credits at the normal rate during any leave
with pay.  However, those additional sick leave credits earned by an employee
while on sick leave shall not be available for the employee’s use until the
employee has returned to work.  An employee shall not accrue sick leave credits
while on suspension, unpaid leave, or absence without leave.
   (b)   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 124.38, sick leave may be applied for and
granted for personal illness, pregnancy, injury, exposure to contagious disease
which could be communicated to other employees, and for illness, injury or
death in the employee’s immediate family.
   (c)   Employees shall not request sick leave for any purpose other than
those contained in subsection (b) hereof.  Any employee who abuses the
privilege of such sick leave shall be subject to disciplinary action including
dismissal.  The department head may require a physician’s certificate for any
illness reported by an employee who uses sick leave.
   (d)   An employee who transfers from one public agency to another shall be
credited with the unused balance of his accumulated sick leave pursuant to Ohio
R.C. 124.38.
   (e)   An employee may convert accumulated sick leave as follows:
      (1)   Employees who have accumulated at least ninety days of sick leave
at retirement may convert such sick leave to cash at the rate of one day of
regular compensation for every three days of accumulated sick leave.
      (2)   Employees who have completed twenty years or more of service with
the Municipality at retirement, may convert accumulated sick leave to cash at
the rate of one day of regular compensation for every two days of accumulated
sick leave.  However, conversion of such accumulated sick leave may not include
any accumulated sick leave which was transferred from another public agency. 
Such converted accumulated sick leave to cash shall not exceed 150 days. 
Accumulated sick leave in excess of 150 days shall be converted pursuant to the
Ohio Revised Code.
         (Ord.  91-43.  Passed 7-15-91.)
   (f)   The Manager may not advance sick leave.  However, employees may apply
paid vacation to sick leave if he so desires.
   (g)   Part-time, temporary and seasonal employees shall not be eligible for
sick leave.  (Ord.  86-20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
   (h)   Accumulated and unused sick leave in excess of ninety days as of
December 31 of each year, may be converted by any permanent full-time employee
to vacation leave at a rate of three days of accumulated sick leave to one day
of vacation leave.  A maximum of five such vacation days may be acquired by an
employee through such conversion in any one calendar year.  To effect such a
conversion, an employee shall notify the City Manager in writing of the number
of days to be converted, whereupon such conversion shall be made.  In the event
an employee converts sick leave to vacation leave as provided herein, such
vacation leave shall not be subsequently reconverted to sick leave nor shall an
employee apply for pay in lieu of such vacation leave.  (Ord.  87-07.  Passed
3-2-87.)
161.15  BEREAVEMENT LEAVE.
   Full-time employees shall be granted bereavement leave, not deducted from
accumulated sick leave, in the event of the death of a member of the employee’s
family.  Five days bereavement leave [shall] may be granted by the Manager in
the event of the death of an employee’s: spouse, child, step-child, parent or
parent-in-law, sister or sister-in law or her children, brother or brother-in-
law or his children son-in-law, daughter-in-law, grandparent, grandparent-in-
law, grandchild, or any relative residing within the same household as the
employee.  These designations shall include step or half blood relatives in
these categories.
   Bereavement leave may be used to attend the funeral, make funeral
arrangement or attend to other matters directly related to the death of the
family member.
(Ord. 04-47.  Passed 7-6-04.)   
161.16  LEAVE OF ABSENCE.
   The Manager may grant leave without pay up to a maximum of sixty continuous
days for personal business or for any other reason, upon application by the
employee.  Any request for leave of absence in excess of sixty continuous days
shall be subject to approval of Council.  If such request is granted, the
employee retains all rights and privileges under this but shall be recognized
as being inactive and shall cease to accrue sick leave.
(Ord. 95-43.  Passed 7-17-95.)
161.17  TRAINING LEAVE.
   (a)   Upon written application, an employee may request paid leave and
expense reimbursement to attend training sessions which are directly related to
his/her job performance.  If deemed necessary, the Manager may require that the
employee sign an employment contract which binds the employee to the Municipal
service.  As a general rule, one dollar ($1.00) in wages, travel expense,
accommodations, tuition and/or meals should require one day of employment after
returning from the training session.  This rule does not preclude the use of
other agreements derived through negotiations or other method.
   
   (b)   Any employee terminating service within the period covered by the
agreement shall have the balance of the training costs withheld from his final
pay as reimbursement for such training.  (Ord. 86-20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
161.18  MILITARY AND JURY LEAVE.
   Employees on military or jury duty may, with proper documentation, apply for
the difference between military or jury pay and his regular wages. (Ord. 86-
20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
161.19  UNIFORM ALLOWANCE.
   Specific regulations regarding uniform allowances shall be outlined in
departmental regulations.  However, the City shall provide weapons, badge,
leather goods and other non- consumable items at no cost to the sworn officers
in the Police Department.  All coats, boots and helmets shall be provided to
firefighters in the Fire Department.  Uniform and initial pair of safety shoes
shall be provided for employees of the Public Service Department.  Other
allowances may be established from time to time with the approval of the
Manager.  Part-time, temporary and seasonal employees may be eligible for
uniform allowances.
(Ord. 86-20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
161.20  EXPENSE REIMBURSEMENT.
   All employees upon application and prior approval by the Manager shall be
reimbursed for necessary expenses incurred while on matters relating to their
particular employment with the Municipality, for expenses incurred in the use
of a private automobile or other expenses while discharging duties connected
with their employment.  Reimbursement for necessary expenses shall be on an
out-of-pocket basis with the exception that the mileage shall be paid on the
basis of the current IRS approved rate, after prior authorization by the
Manager. 
(Ord. 05-41.  Passed 6-20-05.)
161.21  RETIREMENT.
   All full-time employees shall participate in the appropriate State-sponsored
retirement fund.  The Municipality shall pay the employer portion as
established by State law.  Part-time, temporary and seasonal employees shall
either waive or enroll in the appropriate retirement system as dictated by
State law.  (Ord. 86-20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
161.22  MEDICAL INSURANCE.
   (a)   To carry out the need for assistance in medical treatment for
Municipal employees, the Municipality shall establish a program of
hospitalization insurance and make participation in the program available to
all Municipal employees, except elected officials, and temporary, seasonal and
part-time employees.
   (b)   The Municipality may contribute sums required for maintaining
comprehensive group health insurance coverage for each full-time employee. 
Provided, further that, all existing Municipal and employee contributions are
hereby ratified and approved and may continue except for elected officials. 
(Ord. 94-15.  Passed 3-21-94.)
   (c)   A group life insurance program will be offered each full-time employee
and elected official.  The Municipality may contribute sums required for
premiums for such group life insurance for each full-time employee.  Premiums
for elected officials shall be the responsibility of the individual insured.
(Ord. 86-20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
161.23  POLITICAL ACTIVITY PROHIBITED.
   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 124.57, no employee shall directly or indirectly,
orally or by letter, solicit or receive or be in any manner concerned in
soliciting or receiving any assessment, subscription or contribution for any
political party or for any candidate for public office; nor shall any person
solicit directly or indirectly, orally or by letter, or be in any manner
concerned in soliciting any such assessment, contribution or payment from any
employee; nor shall any employee be an officer in any political organization or
take part in politics other than to vote as he pleases. (Ord. 86-20.  Passed 7-
21-86.)
161.24  BONDS.
   All employees shall be covered by surety bonds for faithful performance and/
or honesty in the amount of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500).  The
Finance Director shall be covered by a one hundred thousand dollar ($100,000)
bond.  The Village Manager, Clerk of Council, Deputy Finance Director, and
Account Clerks shall be covered by a fifty thousand dollar ($50,000) bond.  All
premiums for these bonds shall be paid by the Municipality.
(Ord. 10-28.  Passed 8-2-10.)
161.25  PERSONNEL FILES.
   A copy of all actions taken pursuant to this chapter and all actions having
a relationship with an employee’s status, performance or compensation, shall be
maintained in a central location.  Employees may request to review their file
in the presence of a supervisor, which shall be granted in a timely manner. 
Any disputes regarding the contents of a file shall be referred to the
Solicitor for a legal opinion on the merits of a specific case.
(Ord. 86-20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
161.26  SUPPLEMENTARY RULES.
   The Manager is hereby authorized to adopt such rules and regulations as are
necessary to carry out the intent of this chapter provided that such rules and
regulations do not conflict with any of the provisions contained herein.  (Ord.
86-20.  Passed 7-21-86.)
161.27  EMPLOYEE COMPLAINTS AND REQUESTS.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE:  Former Section
161.27 was repealed by Ordinance 00-04, passed February 22, 2000.)
161.28  PERS PICK-UP OF MANAGER.
   (a)   Effective January 14, 1994 the full amount of the statutorily required
contribution to the Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio shall be paid by
the Municipality for each person within any of the classes established in
subsection (b) hereof and shall be “picked up” (assumed and paid to the Public
Employees Retirement System of Ohio) by the Municipality.  This “pick up” by
the Municipality is, and shall be designated as, public employee contributions
and shall be in lieu of contributions to the Public Employees Retirement System
of Ohio by each person within any of the classes established in subsection (b)
hereof.  No person subject to this “pick up” shall have the option of choosing
to receive the statutorily required contribution to the Public Employees
Retirement System of Ohio directly instead of having it “pick up” by the
Municipality or of being excluded from the “pick up”.
      (1)   The Municipality shall, in reporting and making remittance to the
Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio, report that the public employee’s
contribution for each person subject to this “pick up” has been made as
provided by the statute.
   (b)   The “pick up” by the Municipality provided by this section shall apply
to the Village Manager, in accordance with his employment agreement effective
January 14, 1994.
   (c)   The Municipality’s method of payment of salary to the referenced
employee who is a participant in PERS is hereby modified as follows:  in order
to provide for a fringe benefit pick up of employee contributions to PERS.
   
   (d)   The total salary for the employee shall be the salary otherwise
payable under the Municipality’s policies.  Such total salary of such employee
shall be payable by the Municipality in two parts: (1) deferred salary and (2)
cash salary.  The employee deferred salary shall be equal to that percentage of
that employee’s total salary which is required from time to time by PERS to be
paid by the Municipality to PERS on behalf of the employee as a pick up and in
lieu of the PERS employee contribution otherwise payable by that employee.  The
employee cash salary shall be equal to that employee’s total salary less the
amount of the pick up for that employee, and shall be payable, subject to
applicable payroll deductions, to that employee.  The Municipality shall
compute and remit its employer contributions to PERS based upon an employee’s
cash salary.
   (e)   The Finance Director is hereby authorized and directed to implement
the provisions of this section to institute the “pick up” of the statutorily
required contributions to the Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio for
the person reflected in subsection (b) hereof so as to enable him to obtain the
result in Federal and State tax deferments and other benefits.  (Ord. 93- 71. 
Passed 10-18-93.)
161.29  RATES OF PAY IN EXCESS OF COMPENSATION SCHEDULE.
   Certain employees whose rate of pay exceeds the maximum amount set forth in
the various compensation schedules amended on June 16, 1997 shall remain at
their current rate of pay until such time as the schedules are increased,
pursuant to Section
161.11, to an amount greater than their current rate of pay.  Thereafter,
Council shall, by motion, determine the rate of pay for each employee, at such
time as it deems appropriate and necessary, in accordance with their respective
compensation schedule established for their position.
(Ord. 97-55.  Passed 7-21-97.)
161.30  EMPLOYEE TUITION REIMBURSEMENT PROGRAM.
   The continuing education and development of all employees is most desirable;
in order to encourage such advancement, an Employee Tuition Reimbursement
Program is offered.  Any full- time employee who has passed his or her
probationary period is eligible for participation in the Employee Tuition
Reimbursement Program.
   The course of study must be reasonably related to the employee’s job, and
the employee must seek approval for participation in the Program from the
Municipal Manager prior to the start of actual course work.  The Municipality
will pay eighty percent (80%) of the tuition and necessary fees and texts at a
two-year degree institution, and sixty percent (60%) of the tuition at a four-
year degree institution, for courses related to the development of a regular
full-time employee.
   Upon satisfactorily completing the course and  achieving a final grade of B
or better, the employee must provide the Finance Department with proof of
satisfactory completion, as well as a copy of proof of tuition and receipts for
necessary fee and text payments, in order to receive reimbursement.  Failure to
achieve a grade of B or better, or failure to submit proof of satisfactory
completion will result in the forfeiture of reimbursement.
   Voluntary enrollment in courses shall normally occur outside of scheduled
work hours.  No wages or other compensation shall be earned while attending
courses.  Where it is impossible to obtain the educational opportunities other
than during scheduled work hours, the employee’s supervisor may authorize
attendance during the normal workday.
   Employees who enroll in the Employee Tuition Reimbursement Program and
terminate their employment with the Municipality within two years of completion
of a course will have their reimbursement reduced on the following pro-rated
basis:
 
Date of Termination           Percent of Reimbursement Reduced by:
                              2 Year Program 4 Year Program
0-12 months following course  100%           100%
13-18 months following course 60%            60%
19-24 months following course 40%            40%
 
   Any reimbursement owed by the participant will be deducted from the
employee’s last paycheck.
   The Municipal Manager is authorized to waive this requirement under unusual
and justifiable circumstances such as spousal  relocation, death of an
immediate relative forcing employee relocation or termination of employment due
to unusual circumstances, etc.
   The maximum reimbursement which participants of the Program may receive
during any calendar year is one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00).
(Ord. 00-18.  Passed 4-3-00; Ord. 16-16.  Passed 7-5-16.)
161.31  COMPENSATORY TIME IN LIEU OF OVERTIME PAY.
   (a)   Employees eligible for overtime may elect to take compensatory time
off in lieu of overtime pay, for any overtime worked, on a time and one-half
basis, at a time approved by the Municipal Manager to avoid disruption of
Municipal services.
   (b)   Accrued compensatory time shall not exceed twenty-four hours, unless
authorized in writing by the Municipal Manager, and shall be taken on or before
June 30 of each year.  Any unused compensatory time as of July 1 of each year
shall be paid at the employee’s wage rate in effect at the time the
compensatory time was accrued.
   (c)   Designation of compensatory time shall be made in the same manner as
any other leave is applied for.  (Ord.  00-51.  Passed 8-7-2000.)
161.311 COMPENSATORY TIME FOR SALARIED EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   Salaried employees are not eligible for overtime pay.  However,
salaried employees may take unpaid compensatory time off as approved by the
Municipal Manager, for overtime worked.  The time off must be approved, in
advance, by the Municipal Manager in order to avoid disruption of municipal
services.  (Ord. 12-33.  Passed 6-18-12.)
 
   (b)   Salaried employees may accrue unpaid compensatory time.  However,
under no circumstances shall any accrued unpaid compensatory time exceed 24
hours, unless authorized in writing by the Municipal Manager.  Compensatory
time for salaried employees shall be accrued on an hour for hour basis.  Under
no circumstances shall any accrued unpaid compensatory time be paid to any
salaried employee.  (Ord. 13-20.  Passed 4-15-13.)
161.32  PERS CONTRIBUTION PICK UP.
   (a)   Effective July 10, 2000, the full amount of the statutorily required
contributions to the Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio shall be
withheld from the gross pay of each person within any of the classes
established in subsection (b) hereof and shall be “picked up” (assumed and paid
to the Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio) by the Village of
Germantown.  This “pick up” by the Village of Germantown is, and shall be
designated as, public employee contributions and shall be in lieu of
contributions to the Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio by each person
within any of the classes established in subsection (b) hereof.  No person
subject to this “pick up” shall have the option of choosing to receive the
statutorily required contribution to the Public Employees Retirement System of
Ohio directly instead of having it “picked up” by the Village of Germantown or
of being excluded from the “pick up”.
   The Village of Germantown shall, in reporting and making remittance to the
Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio report that the public employees
contribution for each person subject to this “pick up” has been made as
provided by the statute.
   (b)   The “pick up” by the Village of Germantown provided by this section
shall apply to all persons that are employees of the Village of Germantown who
are or become contributing members of the Public Employees Retirement System of
Ohio.
   (c)   The Village’s method of payment of salary to employees who are
participants in PERS is hereby modified as follows, in order to provide for a
salary reduction pick-up of employee contributions to PERS.
   (d)   The total salary for each employee shall be the salary otherwise
payable under the Village policies.  Such total salary of each employee shall
be payable by the Village in two parts: (a) deferred salary and (b) cash
salary.  An employee’s deferred salary shall be equal to that percentage of
that employee’s total salary which is required from time to time by PERS to be
paid as an employee contribution by that employee, and shall be paid by the
Village to PERS on behalf of that employee as a pick-up and in lieu of the PERS
employee contribution otherwise payable by that employee.  An employee’s cash
salary shall be equal to that employee’s total salary less the amount of the
pick-up for that employee, and shall be payable, subject to applicable payroll
deductions, to that employee.  The Village shall compute and remit its employer
contribution to PERS based upon an employee’s total salary.  The total combined
expenditures of the Village for such employees’ total salaries payable under
applicable Village policies and the pick-up provisions of this section shall
not be greater than the amounts it would have paid for those items had this
provision not been in effect.
   (e)   The Finance Director is hereby authorized and directed to implement
the provisions of this section to institute the “pick up” of the statutorily
required contributions to the Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio for
those persons reflected in subsection (b) hereof so as to enable them to obtain
the result in Federal and State tax deferments and other benefits.  (Ord.  00-
36.  Passed 6-5-2000.)

2000.)
   (c)   The Village of Germantown’s method of payment of salary to employees
who are participants in the Police and Firemen’s Disability and Pension Fund
(PFDPF) is hereby modified as follows, in order to provide for a salary
reduction of “pick-up” of employee contributions to the Police and Firemen’s
Disability and Pension Fund (PFDPF).
   (d)   The total salary for each employee shall be the salary otherwise
payable under the Village of Germantown’s policies.  Such total salary of each
employee shall be payable by the Village of Germantown in two parts: (a)
deferred salary and (b) cash salary.  An employee’s deferred salary shall be
equal to the percentage of that employee’s total salary which is required from
time to time by the Police and Firemen’s Disability and Pension Fund (PFDPF) as
an employee contribution by the employee and shall be paid by the Village of
Germantown to the Police and Firemen’s Disability and Pension Fund (PFDPF) on
behalf of that employee as a “pick up” and in lieu of the Police and Firemen’s
Disability and Pension Fund (PFDPF) employee contribution otherwise payable by
that employee.
   An employee’s cash salary shall be equal to that employee’s total salary
less the amount of the “pick-up” for that employee, and shall be payable,
subject to applicable payroll deductions, to that employee.  The Village of
Germantown shall compute and remit its employer contribution to the Police and
Firemen’s Disability and Pension Fund (PFDPF) based upon an employee’s total
salary.  The total combined expenditures of the Village of Germantown for such
employees’ total salaries payable under applicable Village of Germantown
policies and the “pick-up” provisions of this section shall not be greater than
the amounts it would have paid for those items had this provision not been in
effect.
   (e)   The Finance Director is hereby authorized and directed to implement
the provisions of this section to institute the “pick up” of the statutorily
required contributions to the Police and Firemen’s Disability and Pension Fund
(PFDPF) for those persons reflected in subsection (b) hereof so as to enable
them to obtain the result in Federal and State tax deferments and other
benefits.
(Ord.  00-37.  Passed 6-5-2000.)

CHAPTER 163
Municipal Buildings
163.01   No smoking policy by Manager.
 
 
163.01  NO SMOKING POLICY BY MANAGER.
   (a)   The Village Manager is hereby directed to establish a no smoking
policy for all Municipally owned structures and vehicles.
   (b)   The Village Manager is hereby authorized to amend such no smoking
policy as he deems appropriate and necessary.
(Ord. 93-01.  Passed 2-1-93.)
ADMINISTRATIVE ORDER #47
February 1, 1993
Effective April 3, 1993
No Smoking Policy
   This smoking policy is designed to foster the health and safety of all
Village of Germantown employees and its citizens.  It is also intended to
protect Village resources and promote efficiency.  To that end, this policy
prohibits smoking in all Village facilities and vehicles.
   Smoking poses a significant risk to the health of the smoker.  It can damage
sensitive technical equipment and can be a safety hazard.  Nonsmokers with
chronic heart or lung disease can experience severe distress when exposed to
sufficient concentrations of second-hand smoke.  Many allergic individuals and
the majority of healthy nonsmokers report discomfort when exposed to second-
hand smoke on the job.  The U.S. Surgeon General has determined that
involuntary smoking is a cause of disease, including lung cancer, in healthy
nonsmokers.
   The citizens of Germantown have the right to enter the Municipal Building
without being exposed to smoke.  Because the current set up of the building is
such that all areas are open to public visitation, no areas will be exempt from
the smoking policy.  Separate areas for smoking cannot be made available. 
Additionally, all areas of the building contain sensitive equipment and files
which could be damaged or destroyed by fire, ashes and smoke.  This policy
shall extend to include any areas where combustible fumes can collect, areas
where chemicals are used and all other designated areas where an occupational
hazard might exist.
   This policy shall be in effect (1) month after the effective date of
Ordinance 93-01.  The Village shall provide at the cost of the Municipality, a
smoking cessation program through Western Ohio Health Care and Good Samaritan
Hospital.  Interested employees should contact the Manager's office
immediately.
   Employees that violate the no smoking policy will be subject to appropriate
disciplinary measures.
   Visitors or guests in Municipal facilities or vehicles shall be requested to
refrain from smoking or to leave the premises.
   Everyone's cooperation in this effort is appreciated.
TITLE SEVEN- Judicial
Chap.
171. Mayor's Court
CHAPTER 171
Mayor's Court
   EDITOR'S NOTE: The Mayor has jurisdiction to hear and determine any
prosecution for the violation of a Municipal ordinance, and has jurisdiction in
all criminal causes involving moving traffic violations occurring on State
highways located within the corporate limits, subject to the right of the
defendant to trial by jury and before an impartial magistrate.
   Ohio R.C. 2945.17 provides that an accused has a right to be tried by a jury
at any trial in any court for the violation of any Ohio statute or of any
Municipal ordinance, except in cases in which the penalty involved does not
exceed a fine of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). Ohio R.C. 2937.08 and
Criminal Rule 23(A) provide that if the court in which a defendant is charged
with an offense is not a court of record (the Mayor's Court), and the charge is
such that a right to a jury trial exists, such matter shall not be tried before
him and shall be transferred to a court of record in the County if the
defendant:
      (a)    Does not waive his right to trial by jury in a serious offense
case for which the penalty established by law includes confinement for more
than six months, or
      (b)    Demands a jury trial in a petty offense case in which the penalty
prescribed is a fine greater than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) and/or
imprisonment for not more than six months. "Such demand must be in writing and
filed with the clerk of court not less than ten days prior to the date set for
trial, or on or before the third day following receipt of notice of the date
set for trial, whichever is later. Failure to demand a jury trial as provided
in this subdivision is a complete waiver of the right thereto. "
   In Ward v. Village of Monroeville, Ohio, 93 S. Ct. 80 (1972), the United
States Supreme Court held that where the mayor before whom the defendant was
compelled to stand trial was responsible for municipal finances and the mayor's
court provided a substantial portion of municipal revenues, defendant was
denied a trial before a disinterested and impartial magistrate as guaranteed by
the due process clause of the United States Constitution.
   The Supreme Court of Ohio has adopted the "Ohio Traffic Rules" which
prescribe the procedure to be followed in the Mayor's Court in traffic cases.
Rule 9(A) thereof states the jury demand shall be made pursuant to Criminal
Rule 23 referred to above. Rule 9(B) sets forth the conditions under which the
Mayor may hear a traffic case incorporating therein the holding in Ward v.
Village of Monroeville as further interpreted in_State, ex rel. Brockman v.
Procter, 35 Ohio st. 2d 79 (1973): "Where, in a mayor's court, a defendant is
entitled to a jury trial and a jury demand is made pursuant to Criminal Rule
23, the Mayor shall transfer the case pursuant to subdivision (C). If a jury
demand is not made pursuant to Criminal Rule 23, and (or?) the defendant waives
his right to jury trial in writing, a mayor may try the case if (1) his
compensation as a judge is not directly dependent upon criminal case
convictions, or (2) he is not the chief executive and  administrative officer
of the municipality and as such responsible for the financial condition of the
municipality. Guilty and no contest pleas may be taken by any mayor including
mayors whose compensation as a judge is directly dependent upon criminal case
convictions and mayors who as chief executive and administrative officer of the
municipality are responsible for the financial condition of the municipality. "
   The procedure for transferring a case to a court of record is set forth in
Rule 9(C): "Where a transfer is required, the mayor's court shall make a
written order directing the defendant to appear at the transferee court,
continuing the same bail, if any, and making appearance before the transferee
court a condition of bail, if any. Upon transfer, the mayor's court shall
transmit to the clerk of the transferee court the ticket and all other papers
in the case, and any bail taken in the case. Upon receipt of such papers the
clerk of the transferee court shall set the case for trial and shall notify the
defendant by ordinary mail of his trial date. "
   Rule 13 provides that a court shall establish a traffic violation bureau and
specifies certain restrictions as to the designated offenses and schedule of
fines to be accepted as waiver payment in lieu of court appearance.
